review_title: This place will burn you out

job_title: PSR I in Dublin, CA

review_title: No work life respect and consistent break violations
job_title: Medical Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA

Have been with the company a long time and compared to other medical providers such as Stanford, I am underpaid. 

Poor benefits for employees that need to take leave to care for children or themselves when they get Covid. We’ve all used up all of our PTO either because of employee requested time off or due to family illness and quarantine requirements. 
People are afraid to get sick because they can’t afford to take the time off anymore.

job_title: Physician in Burlingame, CA
pros: PAMF does pay more than other health organizations, however, there is a catch.
cons: PAMF is a terrible place to work, mainly because of unethical practices from the leadership.  The Urgent Care Clinic at the Mills-Peninsula Division, for example, is staffed by very incompetent doctor leaders who have absolutely no empathy for patients or the doctors they are managing.  I work as a doctor there, and day after day, I see the doctors who are considered our leaders purposefully overcharge patients for excessive tests (e.g. pregnancy testing in 7 year old girls) so that they can get paid more for billing more.  In fact, all of us doctors were put in trainings to teach us how to bill the patient more.  We are even in meetings where some of the top paid doctors discuss how to use tax evasion to our benefit.  Several doctors, the good ones, have all quit, so this place is very desperate in hiring.  Some of the other departments may have better leaders, but overall, PAMF is under a productivity model, where the doctors are under pressure to bill more at the patient's expense so that they can get paid more proportionally themselves.  Additionally, there is a huge gender bias.  If you start unveiling the dirt, the male doctors are praised for unethical practices described above and thus are paid more.  When female doctors speak up, they are usually labeled as "difficult" or "not a team player."  It is very sad to me that a healthcare establishment can be so greedy, unfair, and unethical.

job_title: CCMA/ASCP Phlebotomist in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Great place to work. Family environment.
cons: I wish I could start earlier in the morning!

job_title: Patient Services Coordinator in Los Gatos, CA
pros: It is different for every location/specialty
cons: Hard to make quick career growth after this step

job_title: Doctor in San Jose, CA
pros: Not a bad place to work.
cons: Nothing bad about it either

job_title: PSR I in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Great Benefits and some coworkers
cons: Lack of staff due to management

review_title: I have enjoy my many years of work with the clinic and would recommend it to all my friends for a job.
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Fremont, CA
pros: Benefit packages have been fair and competitve for all of my job titles. They are very pro active in helping people achieve the most like education to climb up the company ladder.  People are friendly and really seem to care about each other's lives making it a family like atmosphere. It is very much a part of the community and has been since the doors first opened in 1984. The care we deliver brings back many generations from the same families that started in the early days.
cons: Growth. It started out as a small local clinic and had grown into this big corporation. Some of the it has been great like Elecltronic medical records and local specialty departments. Others not so with the downsizing and a few friends jobs eliminated. That was tough but in the long run this clinic will be around for many years to serve this community.

job_title: Clinical Coordinator in Burlingame, CA
pros: Great benefits & great environment
cons: No cons that I can think of

job_title: Clinical Dietitian and Diabetes Educator in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The clinic functions at state-of-the-art, leading edge of healthcare. My department encouraged me to function independently, and develop behavior modification techniques to gain rapport with my clients as I deemed appropriate. Department team spirit came naturally as each member was respected and everyone supported each other. Our manager understood each of us personally, supported us and encouraged us to expand and take on new focuses when ready to do so, to keep our professional experience fresh and well-rounded with new learning and growth to keep pace with the field.
cons: I am aware that not every employee in other departments shared my positive image for the company. However I have no complaints or concerns as it was a great working environment for me throughout my decade of employment there!

job_title: Patient Resource Representative in Mountain View, CA
pros: Consistant paycheck and good benifits.  Working with people is the greatest fun!!!! Our focus is to help patients. Everyday there is something new that keeps the job interesting.  I feel my department works as a team so we often help each other with problem solving.  I appreciate that the ones who handle hiring doctors are good at getting the best in our area. I have been encouraged that even speaking with other locations, I see the focus is helping patients.
cons: Needs more consistant communication throughout all departments of any changes.  One department may know something that doesn't get communicated to the other.  We can't work as a team when there is a lack of communication. Since we are now a large corporation, I feel that working as a team for patients has to be our focus.   I would love to get rid of negative employees.

job_title: Endoscopy Tech in Mountain View, CA
pros: Their cafeteria food is amazing, albeit a bit on the pricey side for some people. Good benefits and the pay is pretty good.
cons: We+You? What a joke. It's WE and only WE. They don't care about their employees. They only care about themselves. I was employed by mistake and instead of manning up to their mistake they instead tried to find any fault or mistake of mine. They promised to train me but never tried nor gave me a chance. The doctors wanted someone different and instead of saying "you're actually not qualified, we have to let you go," they instead constantly harassed me about policies while turning a blind eye to the same faults done by other staff. They made up customer complaints to put me on probation and then sent me home after numerous "complaints from staff." I can't believe how scummy they are. I was a patient all my life but this has switched me to Kaiser. Lesson to learn: TRUST NO ONE. WATCH OUT FOR YOUR OWN BACK AND DO YOUR JOB. NO ONE IS YOUR FRIEND AND THEY WILL STAB YOU IN THE BACK AND THROW YOU UNDER THE BUS AT ANY MOMENT.

review_title: Listen to your patients and staff
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: PAMF is a solid place to work in terms of pay, benefits, hours, and ability to advance. The recent conversion from IDX to Epic was horrid, and it's good to be on the other side of that transition.
cons: Downsides include management not listening to their patients or staff. Patients go through hell to get their refills. Faxes aren't received, calls aren't returned and the staff gets an earful based on this antiquated system. We have the ability to manage our patients within their EHR's--why can't we go to a full e-refill system?

job_title: Benefits Advisor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: You will do great if your circle of friends are all managers or in I.T. who can cover up your shady secrets while ruining innocent employees reputations....
cons: When you receive evidence in an email that was not meant for you but the manager who sent it had her old neighbor in I.T. Delete all evidence that she had her friend lie on an application and trained her via Email so she seems like she knows what she’s doing...and overhear all meetings giving her friends a heads up that they will get Layed off if they don’t hurry up and transfer over the hill... so if you’re not the manager’s personal monkey then you’re pretty much screwed... she lets her friends to extended lunches without clocking out... thus abusing her power ... she asked Bryan once... how long the videos are kept for , for a reason... to cover herself....

review_title: Worked hard and was still unappreciated.
job_title: Laboratory Assistant in Dublin, CA
pros: 30 minute lunches mean you go home sooner and 8 hour PTO per pay period. Benefits aren’t the greatest but they do kick in after only 30 days of employment.
cons: CLICKY. Back-stabbing. Cutthroat. Non-union environment means no job security which means employees are willing to take out someone they think is a threat to them BY ANY MEANS NECESSARY. Favoritism is definitely and issue here....management fraternizes with employees....employees talk about each other right next to each other...no subtlety here!  Probationary period is 6 MONTHS LONG. Put it this way-a LOT can happen within 6 months. Also, the cutthroat attitude from employees could be because Kaiser is opening down the street soon and they know that their parents are going to realize they have been robbing them BLIND and will start RUNNING in droves to Kaiser. Pamf, please stop being a CORPORATION and remember that it’s about the patient, not your POCKETS.

review_title: You will work hard,  but there is opportunity to grow!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Lots of opportunity to move around the organization, especially since it is part of the Sutter Health network. Access to resources and information. Rich benefit plan (though expensive when covering dependents). Very competitive salary ranges for industry, but you will work for it! If you are looking for challenge and opportunity to make suggestions or lead projects, PAMF is a great place to work. They are constantly finding ways to improve, though slow going, it's nice to know there are always things to do and ways to contribute.
cons: Leadership is always available to staff, but  not always very clear or decisive on company changes or projects. There truly is a very huge work load; some people thrive in that environment, but others may become overly stressed out. There are times when the company implements a new process or program and they haven't quite thought out all the possible areas where there could be issues and it causes some 'back-peddling'.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Nothing good I can say, honestly.
cons: PTO, vacation, sick time, and holiday pay all combined. Health Insurance: EPO and PPO you still have to stay within Sutter Health physicians. Pay definitely could be better. Whether you're a physician, nurse, MA, technician, or PSR (it really doesn't matter what position you hold) you're are constantly talked down to or belittled. I'm not saying all colleagues are this way but 75% out of 100% are.  Managers and  supervisors really don't give two sh*ts about their employees.  There is this "notify your manager or supervisor no later than 2 weeks prior or no earlier than 2 months for PTO to be approved." One time I gave my supervisor a notice that I was going in for a doctors appointment 1 week in advance due to some personal issues I had going on and he let me know that it was going to count against my attendance since I gave a late notice.  Which is BS! Excuse my french. The turn around here is ridiculous since I started in March.

job_title: Shareholder in Mountain View, CA
pros: I have worked at Palo Alto Medical foundation my entire professional career. It was a great place to work. Physicians led our group we voted on major decision and created resources for patients. We have a great EMR system and a multiple locations to refer our patients
cons:
Over the last 4 years the tone of our group has changed. Since Sutter Health took over the emphasis is not on patient safety and well being but rather on productivity.
Physicians are beaten down and keep cutting their hours. Our concerns and worries are dismissed.  There is an upside down structure where physician is at the bottom and administrators are put at the top. We can not keep good employees. They are harrased and written up. Several site leaders clearly suffer from chronic stress and depression making it impossible to have a positive work environment.

review_title: It used to be more worker friendly
job_title: Medical Coding Auditor in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
It is an active workplace where experience may be gained quickly 
Uses Epic to process claims 
Doctors do initial coding and coders process post Epic scrubber edits
cons:
You have to learn really fast
Don't be too picky about getting it right or you'll never meet the productivity expectations
Management uses "above the line" ideology so if you want all the blame on you, even if it is out of your control, you'll do just fine

review_title: Not what I expected but it's ok I guess
job_title: Analyst in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Comprehensive benefit package, great medical reputation, good compensation, flexible workplace, great work-life balance, ability to move around in different job functions, prize long-term employees
cons: Very expensive medical benefits where we have to pay for half our premium (much more than all the other healthcare organizations I've worked for and even among its own affiliates!), poor management, poor communication throughout company, going through a re-org so things are changing from day-to-day and lack of communication exasperates the low-morale effects of the entire organization, not sure how leaders are chosen when they seem to know nothing and newer people who probably would be better managers at certain functions are surpassed by others who have just been here longer regardless of skill level

job_title: Coordinator in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Ethically responsible organization that strives for excellence in health care.  A company that you can be proud to work for.
cons: Tends to be a sterile and cold business atmosphere, somewhat unwelcoming and unfriendly among PAMF peers.  I am still uncomfortable with the general vibe at PAMF among staff.  It has always seemed guarded and aloof.  Nobody smiles.

review_title: They don't seem to care about the employees!
job_title: in Sacramento, CA
pros: Although I've encountered a few physicians I didn't care for, the majority of them are great.
cons: PAMF/Sutter does not seem to value their employees. They are too busy making changes and saving money to care.  No matter how hard you've worked, how much you've exceeded expectations, it doesn't seem to matter.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Fremont, CA
pros: People you work with, networking, things you learn, a good place for starting healthcare employees, EPO insurance is good
cons: Insurance sucks if you aren't EPO. Your copays are high, high deductibles, not good at all. All of my doctors are at UCSF and I've been there for years and because I want to continue care there, I have to choose the worst benefits plan. The pay is too low for what I do. Most of my money goes to health insurance premiums and I'm one person covering for two positions. It's not worth it at all.

job_title: Or RN in Mountain View, CA
pros: The people. The staff, surgeons and anesthesiologists in particular, are wonderful to work with. The team comes together to provide excellent care.
cons: Whether it be Sutter's influence, or the general direction of healthcare, you are made to feel more like an assembly line worker than a critical thinking, professional care giver. You are expected to go above and beyond, with nothing given in return.  If you don't like it, there's the door. You can easily be replaced.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Light work load. Managers supervisors don't overwhelm you with a lot of work. Which is good for some people, but I liked to stay busy. Nice area to work in. Free parking, and the benefits were excellent.
cons: Not a lot of  work. I worked in a specialty office with 3 patient service representative and a person to check in new residents. A lot of down time and manager expected you to stay busy at all times.

review_title: Best healthcare company I've ever worked for, and non-profit to boot
job_title: Materials Manager in San Carlos, CA
pros: PTO, health benefits, great working environment and staff as far as the surgery centers go!  Very supportive and team-oriented. The best!
cons: I felt overwhelmed in the beginning, but the longer I live, the more I know that that's just me.

job_title: Analyst in Mountain View, CA
pros:
-	Learning and growth opportunities 
-	Trust, respect & very little supervision
-	Health insurance and time-off benefits
-	Convenient locations in Silicon Valley
cons:
-	Outdated technology (EPIC, Windows 2007 (!!!), poor user interface website) 
-	Mediocre IT 
-	Lack of “innovation culture”
-	Managers promote based on seniority instead of skills
-	Politics (happens when people get promoted based on contacts instead of measurable skills) 
-	Too many executives and not enough people doing the actual work 
-	Wasteful (lavish decorations, big salaries for executives, purchasing from overpriced vendors )
-	Salaries are not competitive compared to biotech companies in the area

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Good benefits
Nice vacation 
Rewarding job to help people
Good work environment when you have the right manager. I have had good ones and not so good ones and in this environment that makes a big difference.
cons: Things tend to be based on seniority instead of skill or quality of work. That can be a a very challenging system depending on where you came from. My previous employers things were decided on skill.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Palo Alto, CA
pros: The company is rule driven and has a professionally administered environment. Of course your experience will be tempered by the team or department you work in. But in general people I have gotten to know over the years are happy with those they work with.
cons: There is a flip side to the rule driven environment. Sometimes the bureaucracy feels so think you could cut it with a knife when it comes to the implementation of organization wide policies and procedures that are not tailored to each individual department's workflows.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good pay, good benefits, very flexible work environment, able to work on meaningful work while being fairly new in the workplace
cons: Huge healthcare system, so doing anything that's remotely innovative moves at a glacial pace, management was completely incompetent (at best) & was more interested in saving face to CEO than actually getting anything done

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Once a great place under Camino Medical Group until the merger with Palo Alto and Santa Cruz. 
Good benefits package, great medical reputation, fair compensation, normal working hours, annual bonuses.
cons: Management does not promote within, compensation is below industry standards, no COLA adjustment for employees that been working 5+ years. Constant micromanagement and overload of work, overworked by the on-going LEAN process. Difficulty getting vacation time off, no promotions offered by long termed employees. Favored employees get promoted regardless of their lack of experience.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The people are all amazing, everyone I worked with was friendly, patient and all moving towards the same end goal of patient care.  The clinic was amazingly organized with patient flow and everyone knowing what there responsibilities were.  I was supported to grow with management and my team.
cons: Not alot of room with the schedule or policies.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Professional &  collaborative work environment. Generous to community charities. Always on the frontier of new medical technologies
cons: Managers who are not trained when new to the role and those at the top who are not willing to train their replacements or give others an opportunity.  No diversity in executive leadership roles.

review_title: Pays low, poor hours, but a good mission
job_title: in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Organization means well.  They are trying to provide a better health care experience as the US heads toward uncertain times in the health care industry.
cons: Poor pay, communicating through management is a cluster-you-know-what.  Too many moving parts in an organization that grew too big too quickly.

job_title: Analyst in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Great providers who look to innovative procedures to help in patient care. Nursing staff is caring and very competent to take the best care possible for their patients.
cons: Sutter Health which now oversees all systems is a Hospital based organization who have yet to figure out the differences in running physician practices. In their efforts to coordinate services between the various sites has created more dysfunction and in fighting between practices.

review_title: I had a great experience working at Palo Alto Medical Foundation
job_title: Project Coordinator in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: I was able to work remotely 1-2 days out of the week, which was a tremendous help with my commute from the East Bay to the South Bay.
cons: The salary difference between working as a consultant and a permanent position was huge, which I kind of understood, but unfortunately couldn't consider at the time.

review_title: PA location. Good place to work, low on the pay scale.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: PAMF provides a great standard of patient care.  Provides a good benefit and vacation package. Great coworkers. I love my patients.
cons: On the low end of the pay scale for RN's when comparing to places such as Stanford and Kaiser. Not a strong nursing Union. PAMF has been in contract negotiations with the nursing Union for almost a year and all they want to do is take take take away from the nurses. A lot of pressure from upper management.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant II in Fremont, CA
pros: Great place to advance your career in healthcare. Benefits are better then a lot of other big medical offices. The management team makes you feel like you are an important part of the team.
cons: Some of the providers can be harsh and demanding. Over worked with not great pay for the Bay Area. Not very welcoming to patients with service animals.

review_title: Palo Alto Medical Group - Shareholder track
job_title: Physician in Mountain View, CA
pros: I get my own care from a PAFMG PCP. The doctors are superior with few exceptions. The patients are the sort expected from third party pay population.
cons: The cons are lack of qualified doctors, especially PCPs. Every PCP seems to be closed to new patients. The management seems fixated on nurse or action era, though these are hard to find and in some ways more time consuming for the physician.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
- job security
- competitive pay (at least for my area of specialty)
- Competitive pay-time-off hours / yr
cons:
- poor communication
- poor management that lack of vision.
- to cut budget, management keeps adding more tasks on employees without realizing it would effect patient care and production

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Coworkers are all professional and generally easy to get along with.  Most everyone will pitch in and help when they see you are needing it.  Supervisors are approachable.
cons: The supreme emphasis on patient/client satisfaction means that there are some individuals that can get very demanding, and they know how to to play the system; but you have no recourse really as everything is geared towards making them happy.

review_title: Competitive salary for a new MA
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant II in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Starting pay is 23.97 if you are certified. Management is ethical and willing to work with your school schedule if you decide to continue your education. They will pay for classes you've passed with a C or higher up to $1000/year.
cons: Impacted practices can make for long wait times which can mean unhappy patients. Probably not a PAMF only thing though.

review_title: The past few years have been very disappointing; this used to be a great organization to work for and I was very proud.
job_title: in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Most of the physicians are considered some of the best medicine has to offer.
cons: If this were a publicly traded organization, I would make bets that it was going to be put up for sale in the not too distant future.

review_title: Great Place to Focus on Patient Care
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: PAMF takes care of their patients well. The ability to grow in the company is huge, with employees frequently transferring to different departments, usually higher than where they were at. PAMF really instills its value and vision into their employees.
cons: They don't pay much.  Not the best place to work if you're just in it for the money.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Los Gatos, CA
pros: Great place to work.  Good people and friendly enviornment.  Company is moving forward and will take some time but will get there eventually.
cons: Palo Alto Medical Foundation is very clicky.  Promotions usually stay within the area and are not likely to promote you unless your department is promoting.  So far not impressed with asking for time off.

review_title: Just a number like every other large corporation
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fremont, CA
pros: The benefits, the patients, the pay, the hours
cons: Management doesn't listen. Training is horrible. The departments are cliques.

job_title: Patient Service Representative/Surgery Scheduler/Department Coordinator in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I learned most of my skills when I was hired as a Patient Services Representative in 1999. I was exposed to endless opportunities and I was able to advance my position in a small amount of time. I met friends that I will have for life.
cons: It can get stressful from time to time.

review_title: Senior Management doesn't care about it's employees
job_title: Manager in Burlingame, CA
pros: Good healthcare benefits  and good physicians.  I worked with some good peers.
cons: Condescension and tantrums by management are tolerated.  HR can't help because management doesn't care.

review_title: Lack of support from managers and supervisors.  Employees were overwhelmed with the work load.
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Burlingame, CA
pros: The patients were always very nice and very understanding.
cons: There were too many doctor's not accepting new patients.  They seem to all be back-logged.

review_title: Cannot wait to find a honest organization...
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Mountain View, CA
pros: Benefits and colleagues. Cafeteria is okay.
cons: Lack of leadership, lack of patient care,  lack of training, lack of transparency. Politics, no real oversight or opportunity in sight for needed improvement.

job_title: Managed Care Coordinator in Elk Grove, CA
pros: This organization is constantly growing and looking for ways to improve. They frequently offer perks to employees like wellness challenges and contests.
cons: They are constantly  cutting costs which cuts into employee appreciation events or bonuses previously offered.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Fremont, CA
pros: values team work, after hours and weekend differential, great team/medical staff to work with (Urgent care) various schedules available for flexibility with school
cons: difficult getting weekends/ vacation time off, mandatory working every weekend and holiday, no promotions offered to hard working candidates

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Benefits and flexibility of schedule is good. If you want a stable job, this is the company for you.
cons: Management has really gone bad. Staff is overworked and do not consider their workload to be a priority as they just pile it on.

job_title: Lab Service Representative in Mountain View, CA
pros: At PAMF, they treat you like family and have alot a resources.
cons: Not giving people a chance to interview for a job in a timely manner.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Very progressive and a culture of continuous improvement.
cons: Less collegiality than before, more backstabbing due to staff downsizing (staff jockeying for position, to stay on after downsizings).

job_title: Surgery Scheduler in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Great environment to work in. Managers and fellow staff work well together. Amazing benefits and competitive pay for the area. Good room for growth if you are a go-getter.
cons: High patient volume and may need to jump through hoops due to budget constraints to make changes happen.

job_title: Health Promotion Coordinator in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: A welcoming team with a lot of potential. Wonderful working environment.
cons: It seems health promotion programs are not all under the same 'roof', but under several different departments. Rationalization should take place.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Good entry point for a new grad LVN or RN in an ambulatory clinic setting that provides multiple specialty practices.
cons: Difficult work culture present in some departments observed.

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in San Jose, CA
pros: Variety of work, many of my specialty fields. 15yrs new surgical techniques.
cons: Don't have any but I'm used to the stress and different personalities.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Interacting with medical staff and wonderful patients
cons: STRICT with time cards - even if you are 1-5 minutes off, there are consequences.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: People are very caring and professional with the job they are doing.
cons: It's been an ongoing transition with the changes the past 2 years so far.

review_title: My experience at Palo Medical Foundation was horrible
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Fremont, CA
pros: The pay was good, the hours were excellent
cons: Micro-managed by supervisors, doctors, and managers. No support from supervisors and you'll have to suck up to management and doctors to keep your job.

job_title: NRCMA in Mountain View, CA
pros: nice clinic doctors are great. hire a lot of young girls so there is always drama. you can work your way up the ladder really quick if you work hard
cons: benefits aren't great. overtime not allowed. hard to get through on the phones. billing department is horrible

job_title: Physician in San Jose, CA
pros: Good people trying to improve healthcare. MAs are nice, fast, polite and co operative. Time off allowed as my convenience.
cons: Low pay, confusing structure of all staff. A lot of construction going on around the buildings. To far to ride my bike t work.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in San Mateo, CA
pros: Great fellow employees, well-organized, great support system, nice to be part of a larger organization, but still have the small company feel.
cons: The management is a little short-sighted. There tends to be too much leeway for poor performers and morale can suffer.

review_title: You'd be lucky to get hired
job_title: LVN in Palo Alto, CA

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Love the management, the people I work with, and the environment. Great place to work!

review_title: This company is a great place to start out when you've been absent from the job scene.
